title: Cardinal number theorems using Axiom of Choice

blocks.name: cardval
blocks.content: The value of the cardinal number function. Definition 10.4 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 85. See ~ cardval2 for a simpler version of its value. (Contributed by NM, 21-Oct-2003.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 28-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: cardid
blocks.content: Any set is equinumerous to its cardinal number. Proposition 10.5 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 85. (Contributed by NM, 22-Oct-2003.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 28-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: cardidg
blocks.content: Any set is equinumerous to its cardinal number. Closed theorem form of ~ cardid . (Contributed by David Moews, 1-May-2017.)

blocks.name: cardidd
blocks.content: Any set is equinumerous to its cardinal number. Deduction form of ~ cardid . (Contributed by David Moews, 1-May-2017.)

blocks.name: cardf
blocks.content: The cardinality function is a function with domain the well-orderable sets. Assuming AC, this is the universe. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-Jun-2013.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 13-Sep-2013.)

blocks.name: carden
blocks.content: Two sets are equinumerous iff their cardinal numbers are equal. This important theorem expresses the essential concept behind "cardinality" or "size." This theorem appears as Proposition 10.10 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 85, Theorem 7P of [Enderton] p. 197, and Theorem 9 of [Suppes] p. 242 (among others). The Axiom of Choice is required for its proof. Related theorems are ~ hasheni and the finite-set-only ~ hashen . This theorem is also known as Hume's Principle. Gottlob Frege's two-volume _Grundgesetze der Arithmetik_ used his Basic Law V to prove this theorem. Unfortunately Basic Law V caused Frege's system to be inconsistent because it was subject to Russell's paradox (see ~ ru ). Later scholars have found that Frege primarily used Basic Law V to Hume's Principle. If Basic Law V is replaced by Hume's Principle in Frege's system, much of Frege's work is restored. _Grundgesetze der Arithmetik_, once Basic Law V is replaced, proves "Frege's theorem" (the Peano axioms of arithmetic can be derived in second-order logic from Hume's principle). See https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/frege-theorem . We take a different approach, using first-order logic and ZFC, to prove the Peano axioms of arithmetic. The theory of cardinality can also be developed without AC by introducing "card" as a primitive notion and stating this theorem as an axiom, as is done with the axiom for cardinal numbers in [Suppes] p. 111. Finally, if we allow the Axiom of Regularity, we can avoid AC by defining the cardinal number of a set as the set of all sets equinumerous to it and having the least possible rank (see ~ karden ). (Contributed by NM, 22-Oct-2003.)

thm carden(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {

  ex(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, c3)), wceq(cfv(ccrd, c0), cfv(ccrd, c2)), wbr(c0, cen, c2))

  cardid2(c0)
  ensym(cfv(ccrd, c0), c0)
  eqbrtrd(cfv(ccrd, c0), cen, c2, cfv(ccrd, c2), wa(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, c3)), wceq(cfv(ccrd, c0), cfv(ccrd, c2))))
  simpr(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, c3)), wceq(cfv(ccrd, c0), cfv(ccrd, c2)))
  cardidd(c2, cdm(ccrd), wa(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, c3)), wceq(cfv(ccrd, c0), cfv(ccrd, c2))))

thm carden(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  ⊢ ((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ c3)→((card ` c0)=(card ` c2)↔ c0[≅]c2))
} = {
  impbid1((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ c3), (card ` c0)=(card ` c2), c0[≅]c2)
  ex((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ c3), (card ` c0)=(card ` c2), c0[≅]c2)
  syl2anc(((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ c3)∧(card ` c0)=(card ` c2)), c0[≅]c2, c0[≅](card ` c0), (card ` c0)[≅]c2)
  3syl(((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ c3)∧(card ` c0)=(card ` c2)), c0[≅](card ` c0), c0 ∈ dom(card), (card ` c0)[≅]c0)
  ad2antrr(c0 ∈ c1, c2 ∈ c3, (card ` c0)=(card ` c2), c0 ∈ dom(card))
  numth3(c0, c1)
  cardid2(c0)
  ensym((card ` c0), c0)
  eqbrtrd((card ` c0), cen, c2, (card ` c2), ((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ c3)∧(card ` c0)=(card ` c2)))
  simpr((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ c3), (card ` c0)=(card ` c2))
  cardidd(c2, dom(card), ((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ c3)∧(card ` c0)=(card ` c2)))
  ad2antlr(c0 ∈ c1, c2 ∈ c3, (card ` c0)=(card ` c2), c2 ∈ dom(card))
  numth3(c2, c3)
  entr(c0, (card ` c0), c2)
  carden2b(c0, c2)
}

blocks.name: cardeq0
blocks.content: Only the empty set has cardinality zero. (Contributed by NM, 23-Apr-2004.)

blocks.name: unsnen
blocks.content: Equinumerosity of a set with a new element added. (Contributed by NM, 7-Nov-2008.)

thm unsnen(class c0, class c1) {
  ⊢ (¬ c0 ∈ c1 →(c1 ⋃ { c0 })[≅]suc((card ` c1)))
  ⊣ c1 ∈ 𝕌
  ⊣ c0 ∈ 𝕌
} = {
  syl6breqr((c1 ⋃ { c0 }), cen, suc((card ` c1)), ((card ` c1)⋃ {(card ` c1)}), ¬ c0 ∈ c1)
  sylbir(¬ c0 ∈ c1, (c1 ⋃ { c0 })[≅]((card ` c1)⋃ {(card ` c1)}), (c1 ⋂ { c0 })= ∅)
  disjsn(c1, c0)
  mpan2((c1 ⋂ { c0 })= ∅, (c1 ⋃ { c0 })[≅]((card ` c1)⋃ {(card ` c1)}), ((card ` c1)⋂ {(card ` c1)})= ∅)
  ax-mp(((card ` c1)⋂ {(card ` c1)})= ∅, Ord((card ` c1)))
  onordi((card ` c1))
  cardon(c1)
  orddisj((card ` c1))
  mpanl12(((c1 ⋂ { c0 })= ∅ ∧((card ` c1)⋂ {(card ` c1)})= ∅), (c1 ⋃ { c0 })[≅]((card ` c1)⋃ {(card ` c1)}), c1[≅](card ` c1), { c0 }[≅]{(card ` c1)})
  ensymi(c1, (card ` c1))
  cardid(c1)
  mp2an({ c0 }[≅]{(card ` c1)}, c0 ∈ 𝕌, (card ` c1)∈ 𝕌)
  fvex(ccrd, c1)
  en2sn(c0, universe, (card ` c1), universe)
  unen(c1, (card ` c1), { c0 }, {(card ` c1)})
  df-suc((card ` c1))
}

blocks.name: carddom
blocks.content: Two sets have the dominance relationship iff their cardinalities have the subset relationship. Equation i of [Quine] p. 232. (Contributed by NM, 22-Oct-2003.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 30-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: cardsdom
blocks.content: Two sets have the strict dominance relationship iff their cardinalities have the membership relationship. Corollary 19.7(2) of [Eisenberg] p. 310. (Contributed by NM, 22-Oct-2003.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 30-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: domtri
blocks.content: Trichotomy law for dominance and strict dominance. This theorem is equivalent to the Axiom of Choice. (Contributed by NM, 4-Jan-2004.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 30-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: entric
blocks.content: Trichotomy of equinumerosity and strict dominance. This theorem is equivalent to the Axiom of Choice. Theorem 8 of [Suppes] p. 242. (Contributed by NM, 4-Jan-2004.)

blocks.name: entri2
blocks.content: Trichotomy of dominance and strict dominance. (Contributed by NM, 4-Jan-2004.)

blocks.name: entri3
blocks.content: Trichotomy of dominance. This theorem is equivalent to the Axiom of Choice. Part of Proposition 4.42(d) of [Mendelson] p. 275. (Contributed by NM, 4-Jan-2004.)

blocks.name: sdomsdomcard
blocks.content: A set strictly dominates iff its cardinal strictly dominates. (Contributed by NM, 30-Oct-2003.)

thm sdomsdomcard(class c0, class c1) {
  ⊢ (c0[≺]c1 ↔ c0[≺](card ` c1))
} = {
  impbii(c0[≺]c1, c0[≺](card ` c1))
  mpdan(c0[≺]c1, c0[≺](card ` c1), c1[≅](card ` c1))
  4syl(c0[≺]c1, c1[≅](card ` c1), c1 ∈ 𝕌, c1 ∈ dom(card), (card ` c1)[≅]c1)
  brrelex2i(c0, csdm, c1)
  relsdom()
  numth3(c1, universe)
  cardid2(c1)
  ensym((card ` c1), c1)
  sdomentr(c0, c1, (card ` c1))
  sdomsdomcardi(c0, c1)
}

blocks.name: canth3
blocks.content: Cantor's theorem in terms of cardinals. This theorem tells us that no matter how large a cardinal number is, there is a still larger cardinal number. Theorem 18.12 of [Monk1] p. 133. (Contributed by NM, 5-Nov-2003.)

blocks.name: infxpidm
blocks.content: The Cartesian product of an infinite set with itself is idempotent. This theorem (which is an AC equivalent) provides the basis for infinite cardinal arithmetic. Proposition 10.40 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 95. This proof follows as a corollary of ~ infxpen . (Contributed by NM, 17-Sep-2004.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 9-Mar-2013.)

blocks.name: ondomon
blocks.content: The collection of ordinal numbers dominated by a set is an ordinal number. (In general, not all collections of ordinal numbers are ordinal.) Theorem 56 of [Suppes] p. 227. This theorem can be proved (with a longer proof) without the Axiom of Choice; see ~ hartogs . (Contributed by NM, 7-Nov-2003.) (New usage is discouraged.) (Proof modification is discouraged.)

thm ondomon(setvar s0, class c0, class c1) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ c1 → { s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 } ∈ On)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
} = {
  mpbiri(c0 ∈ c1, { s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 } ∈ On, Ord({ s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 }))
  mp3an(Ord({ s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 }), Tr({ s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 }), { s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 } ⊆ On, Ord(On))
  mpbir(Tr({ s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 }), ∀(hs0, ∀(hs1,((hs0 ∈ hs1 ∧ hs1 ∈ { s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 })→ hs0 ∈ { s0 ∈ On | s0[≼]c0 }))))

blocks.content: A set is finite iff its cardinal is a natural number. (Contributed by Jeff Madsen, 2-Sep-2009.)

  cardnn(cv(hs0))

blocks.name: unirnfdomd
blocks.content: The union of the range of a function from an infinite set into the class of finite sets is dominated by its domain. Deduction form. (Contributed by David Moews, 1-May-2017.)

thm unirnfdomd(class c0, class c1, class c2, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wbr(cuni(crn(c0)), cdom, c1))
  -| wi(w0, wf(c0, c1, cfn))
  -| wi(w0, wn(wcel(c1, cfn)))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, c2))
} = {
  syl2anc(w0, wbr(cuni(crn(c0)), cdom, c1), wbr(cuni(crn(c0)), cdom, cxp(c1, c1)), wbr(cxp(c1, c1), cen, c1))
  syl2anc(w0, wbr(cuni(crn(c0)), cdom, cxp(c1, c1)), wbr(cuni(crn(c0)), cdom, cxp(c1, com)), wbr(cxp(c1, com), cdom, cxp(c1, c1)))
  syl2anc(w0, wbr(cuni(crn(c0)), cdom, cxp(c1, com)), wbr(cuni(crn(c0)), cdom, cxp(crn(c0), com)), wbr(cxp(crn(c0), com), cdom, cxp(c1, com)))
  syl2anc(w0, wbr(cuni(crn(c0)), cdom, cxp(crn(c0), com)), wcel(crn(c0), universe), wral(hs0, crn(c0), wbr(cv(hs0), cdom, com)))
  syl(w0, wcel(crn(c0), universe), wcel(c0, universe))
  syl2anc(w0, wcel(c0, universe), wfn(c0, c1), wcel(c1, c2))
  fnex(c0, c1, c2)

blocks.name: konigth
blocks.content: Konig's Theorem. If ` m ( i ) ~< n ( i ) ` for all ` i e. A ` , then ` sum_ i e. A m ( i ) ~< prod_ i e. A n ( i ) ` , where the sums and products stand in for disjoint union and infinite cartesian product. The version here is proven with regular unions rather than disjoint unions for convenience, but the version with disjoint unions is clearly a special case of this version. The Axiom of Choice is needed for this proof, but it contains AC as a simple corollary (letting ` m ( i ) = (/) ` , this theorem says that an infinite cartesian product of nonempty sets is nonempty), so this is an AC equivalent. Theorem 11.26 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 107. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 22-Feb-2013.)

blocks.name: alephsucpw
blocks.content: The power set of an aleph dominates the successor aleph. (The Generalized Continuum Hypothesis says they are equinumerous, see ~ gch3 or ~ gchaleph2 .) (Contributed by NM, 27-Aug-2005.)

blocks.name: aleph1
blocks.content: The set exponentiation of 2 to the aleph-zero has cardinality of at least aleph-one. (If we were to assume the Continuum Hypothesis, their cardinalities would be the same.) (Contributed by NM, 7-Jul-2004.)

blocks.name: alephval2
blocks.content: An alternate way to express the value of the aleph function for nonzero arguments. Theorem 64 of [Suppes] p. 229. (Contributed by NM, 15-Nov-2003.)

blocks.name: dominfac
blocks.content: A nonempty set that is a subset of its union is infinite. This version is proved from ~ ax-ac . See ~ dominf for a version proved from ~ ax-cc . (Contributed by NM, 25-Mar-2007.)

thm dominfac(class c0) {
  |- wi(wa(wne(c0, emptycls), wss(c0, cuni(c0))), wbr(com, cdom, c0))
  -| wcel(c0, universe)
} = {
  vtocl(hs0, c0, wi(wa(wne(c0, emptycls), wss(c0, cuni(c0))), wbr(com, cdom, c0)), wi(wa(wne(cv(hs0), emptycls), wss(cv(hs0), cuni(cv(hs0)))), wbr(com, cdom, cv(hs0))))
  imbi12d(wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wa(wne(cv(hs0), emptycls), wss(cv(hs0), cuni(cv(hs0)))), wbr(com, cdom, cv(hs0)), wa(wne(c0, emptycls), wss(c0, cuni(c0))), wbr(com, cdom, c0))
  anbi12d(wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wne(cv(hs0), emptycls), wss(cv(hs0), cuni(cv(hs0))), wne(c0, emptycls), wss(c0, cuni(c0)))
  neeq1(cv(hs0), c0, emptycls)
  sseq12d(cv(hs0), cuni(cv(hs0)), c0, cuni(c0), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  id(wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  unieq(cv(hs0), c0)
  breq2(cv(hs0), c0, com, cdom)
  3syl(wa(wne(cv(hs0), emptycls), wss(cv(hs0), cuni(cv(hs0)))), wbr(com, cdom, cv(hs0)), wf1(cres(crdg(cmpt(hs1, universe, crab(hs2, cv(hs0), wss(cin(cv(hs2), cv(hs0)), cv(hs1)))), emptycls), com), com, cpw(cv(hs0))), wbr(com, cdom, cpw(cv(hs0))))
  inf3lem6(hs0, hs1, hs2, cres(crdg(cmpt(hs1, universe, crab(hs2, cv(hs0), wss(cin(cv(hs2), cv(hs0)), cv(hs1)))), emptycls), com), cmpt(hs1, universe, crab(hs2, cv(hs0), wss(cin(cv(hs2), cv(hs0)), cv(hs1)))), c0, c0)
  eqid(cmpt(hs1, universe, crab(hs2, cv(hs0), wss(cin(cv(hs2), cv(hs0)), cv(hs1)))))
  eqid(cres(crdg(cmpt(hs1, universe, crab(hs2, cv(hs0), wss(cin(cv(hs2), cv(hs0)), cv(hs1)))), emptycls), com))
  f1dom(cres(crdg(cmpt(hs1, universe, crab(hs2, cv(hs0), wss(cin(cv(hs2), cv(hs0)), cv(hs1)))), emptycls), com), com, cpw(cv(hs0)))
  3imtr4i(wbr(com, cdom, cpw(cv(hs0))), wbr(com, cdom, cv(hs0)), wn(wbr(cpw(cv(hs0)), csdm, com)), wn(wbr(cv(hs0), csdm, com)))
  con3i(wbr(cpw(cv(hs0)), csdm, com), wbr(cv(hs0), csdm, com))
  3imtr3i(wbr(cv(hs0), csdm, com), wbr(cpw(cv(hs0)), csdm, com), wcel(cv(hs0), cfn), wcel(cpw(cv(hs0)), cfn))
  biimpi(wcel(cv(hs0), cfn), wcel(cpw(cv(hs0)), cfn))
  pwfi(cv(hs0))
  isfinite(cv(hs0))
  isfinite(cpw(cv(hs0)))
  mp2an(wb(wbr(com, cdom, cpw(cv(hs0))), wn(wbr(cpw(cv(hs0)), csdm, com))), wcel(com, universe), wcel(cpw(cv(hs0)), universe))
  vpwex(hs0)
  domtri(com, universe, cpw(cv(hs0)), universe)
  mp2an(wb(wbr(com, cdom, cv(hs0)), wn(wbr(cv(hs0), csdm, com))), wcel(com, universe), wcel(cv(hs0), universe))
  omex()
  vex(hs0)
  domtri(com, universe, cv(hs0), universe)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.w(wi(wa(wne(c0, emptycls), wss(c0, cuni(c0))), wbr(com, cdom, c0)))
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs1.s(hs2)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm dominfac(class c0) {
  ⊢ ((c0 ≠ ∅ ∧ c0 ⊆ ⋃ c0)→ _om[≼]c0)
  ⊣ c0 ∈ 𝕌
} = {
  vtocl(hs0, c0, ((c0 ≠ ∅ ∧ c0 ⊆ ⋃ c0)→ _om[≼]c0), ((hs0 ≠ ∅ ∧ hs0 ⊆ ⋃ hs0)→ _om[≼]hs0))
  imbi12d(hs0 = c0, (hs0 ≠ ∅ ∧ hs0 ⊆ ⋃ hs0), _om[≼]hs0, (c0 ≠ ∅ ∧ c0 ⊆ ⋃ c0), _om[≼]c0)
  anbi12d(hs0 = c0, hs0 ≠ ∅, hs0 ⊆ ⋃ hs0, c0 ≠ ∅, c0 ⊆ ⋃ c0)
  neeq1(hs0, c0, emptycls)
  sseq12d(hs0, ⋃ hs0, c0, ⋃ c0, hs0 = c0)
  id(hs0 = c0)
  unieq(hs0, c0)
  breq2(hs0, c0, com, cdom)
  3syl((hs0 ≠ ∅ ∧ hs0 ⊆ ⋃ hs0), _om[≼]hs0, ((rec((hs1 ∈ 𝕌 ↦ { hs2 ∈ hs0 |(hs2 ⋂ hs0)⊆ hs1 }), ∅)|` _om): _om ↣ P(hs0)), _om[≼]P(hs0))
  inf3lem6(hs0, hs1, hs2, (rec((hs1 ∈ 𝕌 ↦ { hs2 ∈ hs0 |(hs2 ⋂ hs0)⊆ hs1 }), ∅)|` _om), (hs1 ∈ 𝕌 ↦ { hs2 ∈ hs0 |(hs2 ⋂ hs0)⊆ hs1 }), c0, c0)
  eqid((hs1 ∈ 𝕌 ↦ { hs2 ∈ hs0 |(hs2 ⋂ hs0)⊆ hs1 }))
  eqid((rec((hs1 ∈ 𝕌 ↦ { hs2 ∈ hs0 |(hs2 ⋂ hs0)⊆ hs1 }), ∅)|` _om))
  f1dom((rec((hs1 ∈ 𝕌 ↦ { hs2 ∈ hs0 |(hs2 ⋂ hs0)⊆ hs1 }), ∅)|` _om), com, P(hs0))
  3imtr4i(_om[≼]P(hs0), _om[≼]hs0, ¬ P(hs0)[≺]_om, ¬ hs0[≺]_om)
  con3i(P(hs0)[≺]_om, hs0[≺]_om)
  3imtr3i(hs0[≺]_om, P(hs0)[≺]_om, hs0 ∈ Fin, P(hs0)∈ Fin)
  biimpi(hs0 ∈ Fin, P(hs0)∈ Fin)
  pwfi(hs0)
  isfinite(hs0)
  isfinite(P(hs0))
  mp2an((_om[≼]P(hs0)↔ ¬ P(hs0)[≺]_om), _om ∈ 𝕌, P(hs0)∈ 𝕌)
  vpwex(hs0)
  domtri(com, universe, P(hs0), universe)
  mp2an((_om[≼]hs0 ↔ ¬ hs0[≺]_om), _om ∈ 𝕌, hs0 ∈ 𝕌)
  omex()
  vex(hs0)
  domtri(com, universe, hs0, universe)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.w(((c0 ≠ ∅ ∧ c0 ⊆ ⋃ c0)→ _om[≼]c0))
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs1.s(hs2)
}
